Bullet Hit and Embedded in Block Attached to a Spring

statement.p: A bullet of mass m and speed v_0 is fired horizontally on a block of mass M attached to a spring of spring constant k whose other end is fixed to a wall. The direction of the velocity of the bullet is along the length of the spring. Upon impact, the bullet is embedded in the block.
(a) Ignoring damping, find the amplitude of the resulting harmonic motion.

(b) Compare the energy of the bullet before impact to its energy when it momentarily comes to rest after the spring is compressed, i.e., at the turning point of the oscillatory motion. Is the energy of the bullet conserved? Why or why not?

hint.p: (a) Use momentum conservation to find the velocity after impact, then use this to find the amplitude of oscillations, (b) Energy will not be conserved.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Let V be the speed of the bullet+block together after the impact. Momentum conservation across the impact gives
(m+M) V = mv_0.
Therefore, immediately after the impact they move at
V = \dfrac{m}{m+M}\, v_0.
The moving combo of block and bullet will compress the spring. Since spring force is a conservative force, we will use conservation of energy to figure out the amount of compression. Let x denote this quantity when maximally compressed. At that point the masses momentarily come to rest.
\dfrac{1}{2}\,k x^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\, (m+M)\, \left(\dfrac{m}{m+M}\, v_0 \right)^2.
Simplifying this we get
x = \dfrac{mv_0}{\sqrt{k(m+M)}}.
This is the amplitude of the subsequent oscillations.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
The energy of the bullet before impact is
E_{i} = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_0^2.
At the instant the combo of bullet and block momentarily comes to rest, the bullet has only potential energy
E_{f} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\, \dfrac{m}{ m+M}\, m v_0^2.
Therefore, the loss in energy of the bullet is
E_i - E_f \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_0^2 \left( 1 - \dfrac{m}{ m+M} \right), \amp = \dfrac{M}{ m+M}\, E_i.
Energy of the bullet is not conserved since, upon impact, work is done by the block on the bullet.

problem.title: A Block Attached to Two Springs on Opposite Sides

statement.p: Two springs of spring constants k_1 and k_2 are attached on the two opposite sides of a block of mass m and the free ends of the springs are attached to two fixed supports as shown in . The block rests on a frictionless flat horizontal surface and can move along the line of the two springs. At equilibrium position of the block, the two springs are neither stretched nor compressed.

When the block is pulled a little, say a distance A, from the equilibrium position in the line of the springs and released from rest, the block executes a simple harmonic motion whose frequency depends on the spring constants of the two springs and the mass of the block.
(a) By looking at forces on the block at an arbitrary point in time, find the equation of motion of the block.
(b) From the equation of motion, show that the angular frequency of oscillation is given by \omega=\sqrt{\omega_1^2+\omega_2^2}, where \omega_1^2 = k_1/m and \omega_2^2 = k_2/m.
(c) What is the kinetic energy of the block, when it returns to the equilibrium position after being let go from rest at x = A?

hint.p: (a) When setting up forces, be mindful of the direction of forces from the two springs. (b) Compare with the undamped simple harmonic oscillator. (c) Use energy conservation; both springs have potential energies initially.

answer.p: (a) m a_x = -\left( k_1 +k_2 \right)\,x, (b) \omega = \sqrt{\dfrac{k_1 +k_2}{m}} , (c) \dfrac{1}{2}k_\text{eff} A^2, with k_\text{eff} = k_1 + k_2.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) shows that forces from both springs are in the same direction. Therefore, the x component of the net force on the block is
F_x = -k_1\,x -k_2\,x = -\left( k_1 +k_2 \right)\,x.

Therefore, equation of motion will be
m a_x = -\left( k_1 +k_2 \right)\,x.
Dividing both sides by m we get
a_x = -\dfrac{k_1 +k_2}{m}\,x.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Compring the equation of motion to the equation of motion of simple harmonic motion, a_x=-\omega^2 x, we see that the angular frequency of the block here is
\omega^2 = \dfrac{k_1 +k_2}{m},
which can be written as
\omega^2 = \omega_1^2 + \omega_2^2,
with
\omega_1^2 = \dfrac{k_1}{m},\ \text{ and }\ \omega_2^2 = \dfrac{k_2}{m}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
From the conservation of energy, we note that kinetic energy at equilibrium will equal the potential energy at the end points of the motion.
KE = \dfrac{1}{2}k_\text{eff} A^2,
where k_\text{eff} will be
k_\text{eff} = k_1 + k_2,
based on \omega^2 = \dfrac{k_1 +k_2}{m} = \dfrac{k_\text{eff}}{m}.

problem.title: A Block Attached to Two Springs in Series

statement.p: Two springs of spring constants k_1 and k_2 are glued with a light but strong glue. One end of the combination is attached to a fixed wall and a block of mass m is attached to the other end and the block is placed on a frictionless table as shown in .

(a) Show that the angular frequency of the block is given by
\omega = \sqrt{\dfrac{k_\text{eff} }{m}},
with
k_\text{eff} = \dfrac{k_1 k_2}{k_1 + k_2}.

(b) Suppose the block is pulled a distance A from equilibrium, stretching the two springs in the process, and then released from rest. How fast is the block moving when it returns to the equilibrium position?

hint.p: (a) For displacement x of the block, springs have different stretches, say \Delta x_1 and \Delta x_2. (b) Think conservation of energy with effective spring constant.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Let x be the displacement of the block from its equilibrium position. Let \Delta x_1 and \Delta x_2 be the stretchings of the two springs at the instant shown in . Therefore, we have
x = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2.
We can write the equations of motions of the block and point P between the two springs.
\amp \text{Block: }\ \ m a_x = -k_2\,\Delta x_2, \amp \text{Point P: }\ \ k_1\Delta x_1 = k_2\,\Delta x_2,

Eliminating \Delta x_1 and \Delta x_2 from the three equations above, we find
m a_x = - \dfrac{k_1k_2}{k_1 + k_2}\,x,
which is an equation of a simple harmonic oscillator with effective spring constant ma_x = - k_\text{eff}\, x, with
k_\text{eff} = \dfrac{k_1k_2}{k_1 + k_2}.
Making use of analogy with the simple harmonic motion we have the angular frequency of the block here
\omega = \sqrt{\dfrac{ k_\text{eff} }{m}}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The potential energy stored is
U = \dfrac{1}{2}k_1 (\Delta x_1)^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}k_2 (\Delta x_2)^2,
with
\Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = A
andd
k_1 \Delta x_1 = k_2 \Delta x_2.
From the last two equations, we get
\Delta x_1 = \dfrac{k_2}{k_1 + k_2}\, A,\ \ \ \Delta x_2 = \dfrac{k_1}{k_1 + k_2}\, A.
Using these in U we get
U = \dfrac{1}{2}\,k_\text{eff}\, A^2.
This will be the kinetic energy when block is at equilibrium since at that instant the potential energy will be zero and all energy will be the kinetic energy.
